conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and needs to be predicted which container (E, F, or G) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
Liquid from A (Green) flows directly downward.
Liquid from A hits the brown baffle and is deflected towards the left.
Liquid from A ends up in Container E.
Liquid from B (Pink) flows directly downward.
Liquid from B hits the purple baffle and is directed towards the center.
Liquid from B ends up in Container F.
Liquid from C (Yellow) flows directly downward.
Liquid from C hits the yellow-orange baffle and is directed towards the right.
Liquid from C ends up in Container F.
Liquid from D (Blue) flows directly downward.
Liquid from D hits the blue baffle and is directed towards the right.
Liquid from D ends up in Container G.
Final distribution: Container E receives liquid from A (Green), Container F receives liquids from B (Pink) and C (Yellow), and Container G receives liquid from D (Blue).
After passing through the baffles, the liquids flow into the containers as follows: A → E, B → F, C → F, D → G.
This matches the visual flow depicted in the second image.
